APPENDIX No. 29.

Referred to in Article 1195.

Rules regarding the Allowances for Equipment and Voyage of certain Officers.

Rules made under the Statute 43 Vic., cap. 3, by the Secretary of State for India in Council, fixing the Allowances for Equipment and Voyage of the Governor-General of India, Members of Council of the Governor-General of India, Governors of Madras and Bombay, Commanders-in-Chief of the Forces in India, Bishops of Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay. Dated 3rd of January, 1888.

I.

1. The allowance for equipment and voyage of a Governor-General of India, resident in Europe at the time of his appointment, is fixed at £3,500.
2. Except as declared in these Rules, Govern-
office may be accompanied by three combatant military officers for his personal staff, the expenses of whose passage will be defrayed by Government according to the rules in force in the Military Department as to military officers proceeding to India on duty.

4. For an ex-Governor-General returning to Europe on resignation, a steamer belonging to the Indian Marine Service will (if consistent with the requirements of the public service) be gratuitously provided, to convey him and his family and suite to Suez; but the homeward voyage of the ship thus provided shall not be continued beyond Suez. The ex-Governor-General will bear the cost of entertainment and messing incurred while on board, in respect of himself and his party, according to the rules in force relating to the conveyance of passengers in Indian Marine troopships.

5. No grant from Indian revenues will be made to any ex-Governor-General for his homeward journey from Suez.

6. An ex-Governor-General returning to Europe may be accompanied by two officers of his personal staff, for whom free passages to England will be allowed according to the rules in the Military Department, and also free return passages to India, if they start on their return voyage within two months from the date of quitting India.

7. In the event of a Governor-General dying, and leaving a widow in India, a steamer belonging to the Indian Marine Service will (if consistent with the requirements of the public service) be provided to convey her to Suez in like manner as in the case of an ex-Governor-General. The widow of a deceased Governor-General so returning to Europe may be accompanied by one officer of the personal staff on the conditions mentioned in the preceding rule, and shall bear all such expenses as would, in ordinary course, be borne by an ex-Governor-General returning to Europe.

II.

8. The allowances for equipment and voyage of the Governors of Madras and Bombay, the Commander-in-Chief of the Forces in India, if resident in Europe at the time of appointment respectively, are fixed as follows:

| Position                        | Allowance |
|---------------------------------|-----------|
| The Governor of Madras          | £1,000    |
| The Governor of Bombay          | £1,000    |
| The Commander-in-Chief of the   | £500      |
| Forces in India                 |           |

9. A Commander-in-Chief of the Forces in India proceeding from Europe to assume his command may be accompanied by three combatant military officers for his personal staff, and newly-appointed Governors of Madras and of Bombay, similarly proceeding from Europe to take up their duties, may respectively be accompanied by two combatant military officers for their personal staff, the passages of these officers being provided at the expense of Government according to the rules in force in the Military Department as to military officers proceeding to India on duty; but with these exceptions, Government will make no arrangements for, and will defray none of the expenses connected with, the passage or conveyance of any of the officers mentioned in Rule 8, or of their families, to or from India.

10. An ex-Governor of Madras or Bombay, or an ex-Commander-in-Chief of the Forces in India, or the widow of a Governor or of a Commander-in-Chief who may die in India leaving a widow there, returning to Europe, may be accompanied by one officer of his personal staff, for whom a free passage will be allowed by Government according to the rules in force in the Military Department, and also a free return passage if he starts on the return voyage within two months from the date of quitting India.

III.

11. The allowances for equipment and voyage of Members of the Council of the Governor-General of India, and of Bishops of Calcutta, of Madras, and of Bombay, if resident in Europe at the time of appointment respectively, are fixed as follows:

| Position                        | Allowance |
|---------------------------------|-----------|
| Members of the Council of the   | £300      |
| Governor-General of India       |           |
| The Bishop of Calcutta          | £300      |
| The Bishop of Madras            | £300      |
| The Bishop of Bombay            | £300      |

12. An officer of any of the Indian Services, temporarily residing in Europe, or a military officer transferred from one superior command in India to another during temporary residence out of India, shall not be deemed to be resident in Europe at the time of appointment, within the meaning of Rule 8 or Rule 11.

IV.

RULES made under Statute 24 & 25 Vic., cap. 104, sec. 6, by the Secretary of State in Council of India, consolidating and amending the rules fixing (when necessary) the Expenses for Equipment and Voyage of the Chief Justices and Judges of the several High Courts established under the said Statute. Dated 31st of January, 1888.

39. For the purpose of defraying the expenses of equipment and voyage from Europe on first appointment, there shall be allowed,

To a Chief Justice or Judge of any High Court ... ... ... ... £300

But no such allowance shall be made to any person, who, being in India, is appointed to the office of Chief Justice or Judge, or who, having been in India, is in Europe at the time of his appointment with the intention of returning to India.
APPENDIX No. 29A.

Referred to in the Note to Article 600, Section III, Rule 40.

Extract from the Old Statutory Rules regarding the Pensions of High Court Judges.

Section III.—Pensions.

Chief Justices.

27. A Chief Justice of the High Court at Calcutta after an actual service of eleven and half years as Judge of a High Court, of which period at least five years and nine months shall have been as Chief Justice of the High Court at Calcutta, shall receive a pension not exceeding £1,800 per annum.

28. A Chief Justice of the High Court at Madras and Bombay, and for the North-Western Provinces, respectively, after an actual service of eleven and a half years as Judge of a High Court, of which period at least five years and nine months shall have been as Chief Justice, shall receive a pension not exceeding £1,500 per annum.

Judges.

29. A Judge of a High Court not being eligible for pension at a higher rate under Rule 27 or 28, shall, after an actual service of eleven and a half years as Judge, receive a pension not exceeding £1,200 per annum.

Invalid Pensions.

30. A Chief Justice or Judge who retires on medical certificate after six years and nine months' actual service shall receive a pension not exceeding one-half the amount of pension allowed for the period of service.

Previous Service.

31. In the event of a Judge receiving a pension under these Rules, he will not be entitled to any other pension or retiring allowance.

32. When a Judge, who at the time of his appointment to a High Court was a member of one of the Government services in India, is permitted to retire before completing the full period of service qualifying him for pension as a Judge of a High Court, he shall receive such a pension as he might receive under the rules applicable to the branch of the service to which he belonged when so appointed, reckoning the period of service as a Judge of a High Court towards service for that pension.

APPENDIX No. 29B.

Referred to in the Note to Article 607.

Special Pensions to Barristers.

Special pensions are admissible as follows, but the Officers named in Article 604 are otherwise subject to the 'Ordinary Pension' regulations in Part IV:

(i) After not less than six years and nine months' active service in one or other of the offices specified in Article 604,—an Invalid pension of £300 a year.

(ii) After not less than eight years and eight months' such service,—an Invalid pension of £500 a year.

(iii) After not less than eleven years and six months' such service,—a Retiring pension of £750 a year.

The Active Service of the Officers referred to in Article 604 includes, besides time spent on duty, whether in substantive or acting service, Privilege Leave, Subsidiary Leave, and periods of vacation during which the Officer is not on Furlough or Extraordinary Leave.
The following Regulations are published for information, but it should be understood that they are only selections. Complete copies of the Indian Army Regulations can be seen on personal application in the Military Department, India Office, London, S.W.

INFORMATION REGARDING HER MAJESTY'S INDIAN STAFF CORPS.

REGULATIONS FOR ADMISSION TO THE INDIAN STAFF CORPS.*

1. A certain number of appointments to the Indian Staff Corps will be offered to candidates for admission to the Royal Military College at each Examination.

2. All Queen's cadets (British and Indian) and Honorary Queen's cadets nominated by the Secretary of State for India in Council will have the option of electing whether they will join the Royal Military College for appointment to the Staff Corps, or for commissions in British Cavalry or Infantry. The appointments in the Staff Corps remaining after the claims of the Queen's Cadets and Honorary Queen's Cadets (Indian) have been satisfied will be allotted in order of merit to successful candidates who have elected for the Indian Staff Corps at the Sandhurst Examination.

3. Election shall be final, and no candidate for the Staff Corps will thereafter be eligible for transfer to the Cavalry or Infantry of the Line except by exchange.

4. After the final examination at the Royal Military College a successful candidate will be gazetted as Second Lieutenant on the Unattached List of the British Army, and will be provided with passage to India. He will be required to embark within two months of being gazetted. From the date of first commission to the date of arrival in India he will receive the British pay of his rank.

5. On arrival in India he will be attached to a British Regiment, and will receive Indian pay and allowances as an officer of the British Army. While so attached, leave (excepting privilege leave) may only be granted to him on medical certificate, and during any leave out of India he will be restricted to the British pay of his rank.

6. At the expiration of one year's actual duty with a British Regiment (exclusive of all leave excepting privilege leave) he will be admitted to the Staff Corps in the rank of Second Lieutenant and appointed to a Native Regiment.

7. At the expiration of two years and three months' service from the date of first commission (exclusive of all leave excepting privilege leave) he will be promoted to the rank of Lieutenant, provided he has passed the Examination in the native language by the Lower Standard. Should he not then have passed the Examination he will only be promoted from date of passing. An exception to this rule may be made, with the sanction of the Secretary of State for India, in the case of delay or illness resulting from field service.

8. He will not be permitted to remain in the Service unless during the first three years from date of first commission his retention therein is shown to be in every respect desirable.

9. Within three years of the date of his admission to the Staff Corps he will be required to pass the Higher Standard Examination in the Native Languages and the Professional Examination required under Indian Regulations.

10. Until he shall have passed the above Examinations he will not be eligible to hold any permanent or officiating appointment (regimental or other) except of Squadron or Wing Officer.

11. Should he not pass the Examinations within the period of three years, he will be removed from the Service and be provided with passage to Europe; he may also be allowed, at the discretion of the Government of India, a gratuity not exceeding one year's British pay of his rank.

12. No extension of the period within which the Examinations must be passed will be allowed except on account of delay or illness resulting from employment on field service, and only then with the special sanction of the Secretary of State for India in Council.

13. Any Officers who may from time to time be required to supplement the direct supply from Sandhurst will be drawn from the Cavalry and Infantry of the Line, and the Royal Artillery. Also, any Officer of the British Army who may show exceptional qualifications for service in India, may with the concurrence of the Secretary of State for War, be specially selected for the Indian Staff Corps. Officers appointed under this paragraph will be transferred permanently to the Staff Corps, and will not be permitted to revert to their British Regiments, except by exchange under paragraph 14, and they will

---

* Officers admitted to the Army before the 1st September, 1892, remain eligible for appointment to the Staff Corps to such extent as may be determined, under the Regulations which follow (see p. 236), and all the cadets who passed out of Sandhurst in December, 1891, and all Militia Officers who passed the competitive examination in March, 1892, are considered eligible even if they were not actually admitted to the Army before September, 1892.

† Previous to being gazetted to commissions, Cadets of the Royal Military College, who have secured appointment to the Indian Staff Corps, are called upon to state officially, through their parents or guardians, what special claims (if any) they have on any particular Command in India through the services therein of near relations, and to what command they would prefer to be posted. These statements are forwarded by the Secretary of State to the Government of India, and the claims thus preferred are alone considered in posting officers to the several Commands. No private applications whatever or from what source soever are regarded.

In reviewing the statements, the services in India of the fathers or near relations of the officers are looked upon as giving the latter a claim to the Command which they may prefer. Claims established by such services in any Command will give priority in selection for that Command, if so desired; but the long and good services of an officer in any part of India are considered as giving his son or near relation a right of choice over others who have no claims through such services in India. When all officers having special claims as above have been appointed (subject to the numbers required for each Command), the remainder of officers for appointment are posted in rotation to each of the Commands by roster of seniority, due regard being had to the number of officers required for each Command.
come under the conditions of paragraphs 7 to 12 to such extent as those conditions may be applicable in each case. Second Lieutenants of over two years and three months' service from date of first commission will be promoted to the rank of Lieutenant on appointment, provided they have passed in the Native Languages by the Lower Standard. Officers above the rank of Second Lieutenant will carry with them the rank they hold on appointment to the Staff Corps.

14. An exchange may be permitted between an officer of the British Service and an officer of the Staff Corps, provided both officers have under seven years' service; that the officer engaging into the Staff Corps is fully qualified for staff employ under Indian Regulations; that immediate and suitable employment is available for him; and that he is physically fit for service in India.

15. Under special circumstances or in special cases the Secretary of State for India in Council may deviate from any of the above Regulations.

ADMISSION OF OFFICERS ADMITTED TO THE ARMY BEFORE THE 1ST SEPTEMBER, 1892.

1. An officer serving in India will be eligible to become a Probationer on the following conditions:

I. He shall, at time of application, have completed one year's actual regimental duty whether in or out of India.

II. He shall not, at date of appointment to a Native regiment, be more than 25 years of age.

2. His application must be accompanied by certificates in the Forms A1 or A2 and B, and by a declaration, in duplicate, in the Form C.

3. The period of probation must be passed with Native troops, and the date of joining a Native corps shall be the date of appointment on probation.

4. Should the officer not have passed the Examination in the Native languages by the lower standard before joining a Native Corps, he will be required to do so within 18 months of so joining; otherwise he will cease to be a Probationer.

5. After the expiration of one year from the date of appointment on probation, the Probationer, provided he has passed the Higher Standard Examination in the Native Languages and the Professional Examination required under Regulation, may be admitted to the Staff Corps.

6. On the expiration of 18 months from the date of appointment on probation he will be admitted to the Staff Corps, whether he has passed the above Examinations or not, on production of certificates in the Forms B, C, and D.

7. Should he not have passed the above Examinations before admission to the Staff Corps, he will be allowed a further period of 18 months (or three years in all from date of appointment on probation) within which to pass.

8. Should he not pass within this period he will be removed from the Service.

9. The names of Probationers will be retained on the lists of their British Regiments until they are admitted to the Staff Corps.

10. During the period of probation it will be open to the Commanding Officer of a Native Corps to report that he thinks the officer, either from temper or other cause, is unsuited for employment with Native troops; in which case the Commander-in-Chief in India, should he be satisfied that such is the case, will post the officer to his own regiment or to a battalion of it, if one be serving in India, or, if not, to any regiment or battalion in India pending orders from the Commander-in-Chief.

11. The same course will be followed in the case of an officer who may not, at the expiration of 18 months' duty, be able to obtain the necessary certificates for admission to the Staff Corps.

12. No officer will be allowed to resign his probationary appointment except on sufficient grounds to be approved by the Commander-in-Chief in India, the Government of India, the Secretary of State for India in Council, and the Commander-in-Chief. An officer applying for permission to resign will be required to produce a declaration and a certificate in the Forms E and F, and the Commander-in-Chief in India, if satisfied with the reason given, will at once post the officer to his own regiment or to a battalion of it, if one be serving in India, or, if not, to any regiment or battalion of the line in that country, his resignation being sent forward at once for the final orders of the Secretary of State for India and the Commander-in-Chief.

13. A Probationer obtaining leave out of India, either on private affairs or for more than six months on medical certificate, will be held to have resigned his probationary appointment.

14. Until the completion of three years' service a Probationer shall remain subject to the provisions of the Royal Warrant of the 5th December, 1888.*

15. When an officer is ultimately admitted to the Staff Corps the date assigned to his admission shall be that of his first appointment on probation.

16. An officer shall not be eligible to hold any permanent or officiating appointment, regimental or other (except that of Squadron or Wing Officer), until he shall have passed the Higher Standard Examination in the Native Languages and the Professional Examination required under Regulation.

17. No extension of the prescribed period within which these Examinations must be passed will be allowed, except on account of illness or delay resulting from employment on field service, and only then with the special sanction of the Secretary of State for India in Council.

18. An officer removed from the Service under paragraph 8 will receive a free passage to Europe and a gratuity of one year's English pay of his rank.

19. Under special circumstances, or in special cases, the Secretary of State for India in Council may deviate from any of the above Regulations.

Examinations in Hindustani.

The following are the tests laid down for these examinations:

Higher Standard.
(a.) Writing a translation of half a page of the Bagh-o-Bahar into English.
(b.) Writing a translation of English into Urdu.
(c.) Reading and translating an Urdu manuscript.
(d.) Conversing with an educated native, special attention being paid to pronunciation.

Lower Standard.
(i.) A vivā voce translation from the Bagh-o-Bahar into English.
(ii.) A written translation of a simple piece of English into Urdu.

Professional Examination for Admission to the Staff Corps.

The following are the tests for admission to the Staff Corps in virtue of qualifying appointments in Native regiments:
(a.) The evolutions of a regiment of cavalry or a battalion of infantry (as the case may be) as laid down in the regulations of those services respectively, including skirmishing, duties of outposts, patrols, escorts, advanced and rear guards.
(b.) The charge of a troop, company (as the case may be), or detachment in every position in which it may be placed, musketry instruction, requisitions, returns and correspondence.
(c.) The Indian Articles of War and the Army Regulations, India, particularly all such as affect the conduct of Native troops, their pay, pension, clothing, &c.
(d.) The system of regimental interior economy pursued in the Native cavalry and infantry, and especially in the regiment to which the officer has been attached, including the mode of investigating and dealing with offences, complaints, and petitions from the men, method of keeping rosters for furlough and guard, deductions made from the men's pay and system of accounts, together with the knowledge of every article of equipment used by the men, their cost, and the mode of carrying them.

In the case of probationers for the Native cavalry the examination will include the additional subjects under head (e).
(e.) System of purchase of horses, and the districts whence they are usually obtained, their prevailing defects and good qualities, stable management, general knowledge of farriery, and diseases and injuries to which horses are liable, with their treatment.

The board will satisfy themselves by examination in the field and vivā voce questions that the officer is instructed in the required subjects.

An officer who has failed in one or more of the above tests is required to be re-examined only in those portions of the tests in which he has failed.

Examination for Regimental and Army Staff Appointments.*

Officers of the Staff Corps are not qualified to hold the appointments of Commandant, Second in Command, or Wing Commander, nor to leave their regiments for the purpose of holding any appointment whatever, except that of Aide-de-camp (unless they come within the provisions of the following paragraphs), until they shall have passed an examination in the following subjects:

Part I.
(a.) Cavalry—
In the field:
Command of a regiment in the following circumstances:
Singly on parade.
As a part of brigade.
As advanced or rear guard.
As outpost covering a brigade or division.

Manoeuvring on varied ground (adapting movements to the ground and to a supposed object).

(b.) Infantry—
Equitation.
In the field:
Command of a battalion in the following circumstances:
Singly on parade.
As part of a brigade.
As advanced or rear guard.
As outpost covering a brigade or division.
Skirmishing (adapting movements to the ground and to a supposed object).

Part II.
† (a.) Military law.
(b.) Tactics.
(c.) Field fortification.
(d.) Military topography.

* The qualifications required and Examinations to be passed for the Judge Advocate-General's Department, the Administrative Departments of the Army, the Survey Department, and for Civil and Political Employ, will be found in the Indian Army Regulations.

† Officers who pass Part II, while on leave in England will be required to pass a Supplementary Examination in the Indian Articles of War and Indian Military Law on their return to India. Should they not have passed Part I., they must do so within six months of their return to their appointments in India, failing which they will be required to pass Part II. again.
Officers may be nominated at any time to staff appointments for distinguished service in the field, although they may not have passed the qualifying Examination; but officers so appointed, who are liable to Examination under this order, will be required to qualify within a reasonable time.

The Examination in Part I. is not required from an officer who has held the appointment of Adjutant of a regiment for a continuous period of not less than twelve months.

All officers in the Staff Corps who may have passed the final Examination at the Staff College will only be examined in Part I., and those officers who have passed the Examination for admission to the Staff College in Military Law, Fortification, Topography, and Tactics, will not be required to pass in Part II., provided they held the rank of Captain at the time of the Examination, or were Lieutenants of at least eight years' service. They must, however, pass a Supplementary Examination in the Indian Articles of War and Indian Military Law as laid down in the footnote on the preceding page.

The following certificates will be accepted in lieu of examination, provided they were obtained in the rank of Captain or with eight years' service as Lieutenant:

1. A certificate (Chatham Form 3) of having passed through a course at the school of military engineering, in lieu of the theoretical and practical Examination in fortification.
2. A certificate (Chatham Form 3) of having passed through a course of instruction in Military Topography at the school of military engineering, in lieu of the theoretical and practical Examination in that subject.

PROMOTION.

Under Royal Warrant promotion in the Staff Corps is governed by such Regulations as the Secretary of State for India may make from time to time.

The existing regulations are—

The promotion of Second Lieutenants from the Unattached List is governed by Rule 7 of the Regulations for Admission (page 235);
Second Lieutenants appointed to the Army before 1st September, 1892, are promoted to the rank of Lieutenant on permanent transfer to the Staff Corps;
Officers after 11 years' service, of which four must have been in the Staff Corps, become Captains;
After 20 years' service, of which six must have been in the Staff Corps, they become Majors; and
After 26 years' service, of which eight must have been in the Staff Corps, they become Lieutenant-Colonels.

The periods of four, six, and eight years' service in the Staff Corps are exclusive of all leave of absence except privilege leave and leave rendered necessary by wounds or illness contracted on service in the field.

Time on half pay not exceeding one year is allowed to reckon as service for promotion in the case of an officer placed on half pay on account of ill-health contracted in the performance of military duty, but no officer can be promoted while actually on the half-pay list.

A Lieutenant-Colonel becomes eligible for promotion to the substantive rank of Colonel in the Army after three years' satisfactory service with that rank. Selection for promotion will be made under such regulations as the Secretary of State in Council may lay down.

A Lieutenant-Colonel may, if selected, be promoted to the rank of Brevet-Colonel after four years' service in the substantive rank of Lieutenant-Colonel in the command of a regiment or battalion, or in any appointment which may be considered to be analogous thereto. The regulations under which a Lieutenant-Colonel may be granted the substantive rank of Colonel will apply to Brevet-Colonels also.

Officers above the rank of Lieutenant are also eligible for promotion by brevet as a reward for distinguished service in the field, or for distinguished service of an exceptional nature other than in the field.

Substantive Colonels only will be eligible for promotion to the rank of Major-General.

Promotion to the ranks of Major-General and Lieutenant-General will only be made by selection to fill appointments, or as a reward for distinguished service. There will be an establishment of three Generals.

A Major, substantive or brevet, may be granted the temporary rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, while holding the permanent appointment of Commandant of a Native regiment; and a Captain the temporary rank of Major while holding the permanent appointment of Commandant or Second-in-Command.

Officers in civil employ, after ten years' absence from military duty, are removed from the effective list of the army, and placed on a supernumerary list, rising thereon, under the regulations in force, to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, but to no higher rank.

This condition is, however, not applicable to officers of rank taken for high political or civil employment, or to officers taken for temporary civil or political duties in the field or in newly-acquired territories.

VICTORIA, R.I.

WHEREAS it has been represented to Us that it is expedient to secure, for the purposes of the Government of India, the continuous service on the Indian Establishment of Officers of Our Corps of Royal Engineers.

Our Will and Pleasure is that the following Regulations be established for that purpose, subject, nevertheless, to any modifications which may hereafter appear to Us to be expedient.

Regulations.

1. Officers of Our Corps of Royal Engineers may, with the sanction of Our Secretary of State for India in Council, elect to render continuous service to the Government of India, and the election shall be open to (1) Officers who at the date of this Our Warrant are performing their first tour of service in India, or who may hereafter proceed to India for that purpose, and who continue to serve for a second or third tour, without interruption except by leave, the election being made at any time during such service, not later than six months prior to the expiry of their third tour;* (2) Officers who are now serving on the Indian Establishment, but who have served part of their time elsewhere than in India; (3) Officers who having previously served in India are now serving on the British Establishment; (the election in each of the latter classes to be made on or before the 1st October, 1886†).

2. Officers electing for such continuous service shall enjoy the conditions of Indian pay and allowances at present existing, subject to such modifications of the same as may at any time appear expedient.

3. They shall be eligible for leave under the conditions applicable to Officers admitted to Our Indian Staff Corps on or after the date of this Our Warrant.

4. They shall be subject to the same regulations as to military promotion, and liability to removal from the effective list, as apply to the other Officers of Our Royal Engineers.

5. They shall be required, should occasion arise, to serve elsewhere than on the Indian Establishment.

6. They shall be allowed, under conditions to be laid down by Our Secretary of State for India in Council, and with his sanction and that of Our Secretary of State for War, to exchange with Officers of the Corps serving on the British Establishment.

7. They shall be liable, in view to their becoming acquainted with the progress made in military science and engineering, and to their qualifying themselves for promotion in their Corps, to return to England to do duty at the School of Military Engineering, for such periods and under such conditions as may, from time to time, be prescribed by Our Secretary of State for India in Council in concurrence with Our Secretary of State for War, and such duty shall count as service for Indian pension.

8. The Regulations under which, with the view of securing the flow of promotion in Our Corps of Royal Engineers, Officers of the Corps may be placed on half pay or retired, shall not be held to disqualify the Officers on the Indian Establishment so affected from continuing to hold any appointments in the Civil Departments of the Government of India which they may have been holding previously, and, subject to the discretion of the Government of India, their tenure of such appointments shall be regulated by the Rules which apply to other persons holding similar appointments in the same Departments.

9. Officers permitted to elect for continuous Indian service shall be eligible, except as herein-after laid down, for pensions under the conditions and at the rates applicable to Officers admitted to our Staff Corps after the 1st July, 1881.

10. Service for pension shall be reckoned from date of first commission, and it shall include all service on the effective list and on the half pay or retired list provided for in Article 8 of this Our Warrant.

11. An Officer serving on the Indian Establishment at the date of this Our Warrant, who has served part of his time elsewhere than in India, or an Officer serving on the British Establishment at the same date, who may hereafter proceed to India, shall on retirement receive a pension consisting of the retired pay to which he would be entitled under Our Warrant regulating the retired pay of Our Royal Engineers generally, and, in addition, such a portion of the difference between the said retired pay and the Staff Corps pension belonging to his total length of service as is represented by the proportion his Indian service bears to the minimum total service that would have qualified him for the before-mentioned Staff Corps pension. In calculating the period of Indian service for pension, three years of British service shall be reckoned as Indian service.

12. Should an Officer retire before he has served a sufficient time to entitle him to a pension under the rules applicable to the Staff Corps as aforesaid, he shall be granted only such retired pay or gratuity as he would have been entitled to receive under Our Warrant regulating the retired pay of Officers of Our Royal Engineers generally had he not elected for continuous Indian Service.

13. Officers who have already had periods of leave under conditions which allowed them to count such periods as service for pension shall, in the event of their volunteering for permanent service in India, be allowed the benefit of counting such periods towards pension under the conditions of this Our Warrant.

14. Officers of the permanent Indian Establishment transferred to the half pay list on account of ill health shall come under the same conditions as Officers of the Indian Staff Corps.

15. Our Secretary of State for India in Council shall be the sole administrator and interpreter of this Our Warrant, and shall be empowered to issue such instructions in reference thereto as he may from time to time deem necessary.

Given at Our Court at Windsor, this twentieth day of February, 1886, and in the forty-ninth year of Our Reign.

By Her Majesty's Command,

KIMBERLEY.

* As modified by Royal Warrant of 19th April, 1890.
† Altered to 1st November, 1886, by a subsequent Warrant.
ROYAL ENGINEERS.

REGULATIONS under which Officers of Royal Engineers, who elect for continuous service in India, are appointed to the Indian Class at the School of Military Engineering, Chatham, under Article 7 of the Royal Warrant of 20th February, 1886.

(Reprint of India Army Circulars, February, 1891, Clause 29.)

With the sanction of the Right Honourable the Secretary of State for India, His Excellency the Governor-General in Council is pleased to direct the publication of the following Regulations for the appointment of Officers of Royal Engineers, who elect for continuous service in India, to the School of Military Engineering at Chatham, in supersession of the Regulations published in India Army Circulars, clauses 176 of 1887, 33 of 1888, and 176 of 1890:

1. Every officer of Royal Engineers who has elected to render continuous service to the Government of India under the terms of the Royal Warrant of the 20th February, 1886, will be required, after he has been one year a captain and before he has been eight years in that rank, to join the School of Military Engineering at Chatham, with a view to becoming acquainted with the progress made in military science and engineering, and to qualify himself for promotion in his corps.

2. The course of instruction will last about eight months, commencing on the 1st April.

3. The number of such officers who will be appointed to the School of Military Engineering in any one year will not exceed 15. They will be selected by the Government of India.

4. If in India when appointed, the officer will travel at the public expense, and be provided with passage to England by troopship, and if he return to India on the completion of the course he will be provided with a return passage. He will also receive travelling expenses as from port of embarkation to Chatham, and again as from Chatham to port of embarkation.

5. From date of embarking from India to date of return as above he will receive English pay and Engineer pay of rank. Servant's allowance will also be granted from date of arrival in England to date of embarkation on return, and also for the period of the voyage, except in a troopship, provided that the officer is accompanied by his civilian servant. He will, in addition, while at the School, be entitled to quarters or the usual allowance in lieu and to fuel and light allowance.

6. In the case of an officer appointed to the School while on leave, the period of duty will commence from the date on which he joins at Chatham, and he will receive the above allowances, &c., from that date. He will have no claim to travelling allowances prior to joining, but if he returns to India at the earliest opportunity after completing the course, he will be granted travelling expenses to port of embarkation and a free passage, and be considered on duty up to the date of his arrival in that country.

7. An officer may, on obtaining the assent of his Government, be granted leave on the termination of the course of instruction, or, if on leave when appointed, be allowed to avail himself of any unexpired portion of that leave, but in either case his duty will terminate at the date of quitting the School, and he will forfeit his claim to a free passage back to India.

8. The whole period passed on duty will reckon as service for pension, and also, in the case of an officer under the Civil Service Regulations, for furlough.

9. Every officer is expected, while at Chatham, to pass the examination qualifying him for promotion to the rank of Major, as under no circumstances will an officer be ordered there for a second time.

10. It is to be distinctly understood that an officer who chooses to pass in India the prescribed examination for promotion to the rank of Major will still be required to do duty at Chatham for eight months, in order to make himself acquainted with the progress made in military science and engineering.

11. If, under special circumstances, it is found inexpedient to order home a continuous Indian service Captain of Royal Engineers previous to his promotion to the rank of regimental Major, the officer will be directed to join the School of Military Engineering for the purpose of going through the prescribed course of instruction as soon after his promotion as his services can be spared.

12. Royal Engineer Officers, who have elected for continuous service in India, if appointed while on furlough to the School of Military Engineering at Chatham under Article 7 of the Royal Warrant of 20th February, 1886, may, if they desire it, draw furlough pay and allowances in lieu of English pay and allowances while going through the Chatham course.

The only allowance that can be drawn with furlough pay is lodging allowance at the Indian rate when the officer is not provided with quarters.
QUEEN'S INDIA CADETSHIPS.

1. The claims of all Candidates who are eligible for nomination as Queen's India Cadets are brought forward half-yearly (in the spring and in the autumn) for consideration by the Secretary of State for India in Council, and the nominations are then conferred on the Candidates whose claims are found to be highest, under certain prescribed and established conditions.

2. A Candidate is not eligible for nomination as a Queen's India Cadet if he be under 17 or over 19 years of age on the first of July for nomination in the previous spring, and on the first of December for nomination in the previous autumn.

3. A Candidate is not eligible for nomination as a Queen's India Cadet until he is prepared to attend the entrance examination next following the date of nomination. If, however, he has already been certified by the Civil Service Commissioners as qualified for admission to the Royal Military College, he is eligible for nomination, so long as he is within the prescribed limits of age.

4. If a Candidate who has been nominated in view of his attending the next entrance examination, does not succeed at that examination in qualifying for admission to the Royal Military College, his nomination lapses; but if at any subsequent allotment of Cadetships he is still within the prescribed limits of age, his claims are invariably brought forward for consideration in the same manner as those of all other eligible Candidates. No further application need be submitted by him.

5. The expenses of Queen's India Cadets at the Royal Military College are not payable by the State, except in cases where, after due inquiry, their pecuniary circumstances are ascertained to be such as to justify the payment.

HONORARY QUEEN'S INDIA CADETSHIPS.

6. Honorary Queen's India Cadets will be appointed from—

(a.) The sons of officers of the Indian Army, who were killed in action, or who have died of wounds received in action within six months of such wounds having been received, or from illness brought on by fatigue, privation, or exposure incident to active operations in the field before an enemy, within six months after their having been first certified to be ill.

(b.) The sons of officers of the Indian Army, who have attained the brevet or substantive rank of Major or Lieutenant-Colonel, and have performed long or distinguished service.

7. A Candidate for nomination as an Honorary Queen's India Cadet is not eligible for nomination, and his claims are in no circumstances considered, until he has already attended an examination and obtained qualifying marks in the manner prescribed in the "Regulations respecting admission to the Royal Military College, Sandhurst" (published by the War Office).

8. Only three Honorary Queen's India Cadetships are at the disposal of the Secretary of State for India in each year, the allotment being made in the month of January, when the claims are considered of all Candidates who have already qualified and were within the limits of 17 and 19 years of age on the first day of the previous December.

9. An Honorary Queen's India Cadetship carries with it no pecuniary advantage.

GENERAL RULES REGARDING BOTH CLASSES OF INDIA CADETSHIPS.

10. The prescribed form of application can be procured from the India Office. It should be filled up and submitted by the Candidate himself, and not by anyone acting on his behalf. Unless the Candidate has reached 17 years of age, and is prepared to attend the next entrance examination, his application will be returned to him for submission at the proper time.

11. After a Candidate for nomination as a Queen's India Cadet or as an Honorary Queen's India Cadet has been recorded on the list at the India Office, no further application should be made by him or on his behalf. All the necessary communications will be addressed to him direct.

12. A Candidate for nomination as a Queen's India Cadet or as an Honorary Queen's India Cadet should immediately report to the India Office any change of his address, and he should also report any material changes in his family, such as the death of his father or mother.

13. All Candidates have to make their own arrangements with the War Office for attending the examinations.

There are no India Cadetships at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich.

NOTE REGARDING QUEEN'S CADETSHIPS.

Queen's Cadets are appointed by the Secretary of State for War. The sons of officers of the Indian Army are not eligible for appointment.
LEAVE RULES FOR THE INDIAN STAFF CORPS.

(India Army Circulars, April, 1886, Clause 51, published 16th April, with subsequent decisions.)

I. An officer may be granted,—
Privilege leave under such regulations as may from time to time be in force.
Leave out of India, for no longer period than one year, capable of extension to two years' absence from duty, on the following pay:—

| After appointment to the Staff Corps | ... | ... 200 a year. |
|--------------------------------------|-----|----------------|
| After the commencement of the 5th year's service for pension | ... | ... 250 " |
| Do., do., 15th, do., do., do. 300 " |     |                |
| Do., do., 20th, do., do., do., do. 450 " | |                |
| Do., do., 25th, do., do., do., do. 600 " | |                |
| Do., do., 30th, do., do., do., do. 700 " | |                |

Leave in India, but for the period of one year only, on full military pay, and half the Staff salary of appointment.

II. No extension of leave involving absence from duty for more than two years, whether taken in or out of India, can be granted except on specially urgent grounds and without pay.

III. An officer unable on account of the state of his health to return to duty within the maximum period of two years' absence, will, unless he is under rule 2 specially granted an extension of leave without pay, be placed on temporary half pay or the retired list, as the circumstances of the case may seem to require. An officer will also be liable to be placed on half pay or the retired list should his health require an undue amount of leave, whether in or out of India. This power will be exercised at the instance of the Government of India should the officer be in India, or, should he be at home, by the Secretary of State in Council.

IV. All leave, in or out of India, will count as service for pension.

V. Leave, whether it is leave in India or leave out of India, will not involve forfeiture of appointment, and may be granted at any time, but solely at the discretion of the Commanders-in-Chief of the several armies for officers serving directly under their orders, and by the Governor-General in Council or the Governors in Council for officers of civil departments of the army or of Corps not under the direct orders of a Commander-in-chief.

VI. An officer on leave, whether in India or out of India, will be required to rejoin at once on being recalled to duty, unless certified by a Medical Board as unfit to do so.

VII. The above rules shall apply to—
Officers whose admission to the Staff Corps shall bear date subsequent to the 30th June, 1886.
Officers of the Staff Corps, including probationers, or of the Cavalry and Infantry lists of the Indian Army, in military employment, who may elect them within twelve months of that date.
Officers in civil employ on that date, subsequently reverting to military duty, may elect them within six months from the date of being replaced at the disposal of the Military Department. If such officers who may be on leave when so replaced must make their election at once. Those taking leave within the six months must make their election before going on leave.

They shall not apply to—
Officers in permanent civil employ.
Officers commanding districts or holding other appointments under special regulations as to leave of absence, who continue subject to such regulations.

Note.—The above does not preclude general officers commanding districts, who before their appointment were subject to the leave rules for the Staff Corps, from being granted short leave in India under these rules.

VIII. Officers who, under Rule VII, have elected to come under these rules count all previous leave as service for pension. The position of those who have not elected them remains unchanged.

IX. The Secretary of State in Council reserves the right of making any change in the foregoing regulations which circumstances may require.

Officers who have not elected for the above rules in the manner and within the period laid down in Rule VII have no further opportunity of election, but remain under previous rules. It must also be clearly understood that no modifications of the existing codes will be sanctioned, and that there is no middle course between abiding by them and acceptance of these new rules.

Military officers in civil employ on 30th June, 1886, who may desire to retire direct from such employment, have, on such retirement, the option of electing the new rules.

When it may be necessary to convert sterling rates of pay under these rules into rupee currency, or vice versa, the conversion will be made at the rate of exchange in force for the period when the pay became due, as fixed annually for the adjustment of financial transactions between the Indian and Imperial Governments.

The rules which govern the allowances of officers acting for absentees remain unchanged.

INDIAN MEDICAL SERVICE.

The rules laid down for the grant of leave to officers of the Indian Staff Corps apply equally to officers of the Indian Medical Service in military employ, with the following modification in regard to the rates of pay whilst on leave out of India:—

| After arrival in India | ... | ... 200 a year. |
|------------------------|-----|----------------|
| After the commencement of the 5th year's service for pension | ... | ... 250 " |
| Ditto, ditto, 10th ditto | ... | ... 300 " |
| Ditto, ditto, 15th ditto | ... | ... 400 " |
| Ditto, ditto, 20th ditto | ... | ... 450 " |
| Ditto, ditto, 25th ditto | ... | ... 500 " |

The rules apply to all Medical Officers admitted to the service after the 30th June, 1886, and to officers who may elect them under the provisions of Rule VII.

SUBSIDARY RULES.

1. Officers in permanent civil employment, while they continue in such employment, are not affected by these rules; but if desirous of
retiring on pension direct from such employment, they will, whether on duty or on furlough, be given the benefit of the rule which allows all previous leave to count as service for pension.

It is, however, to be clearly understood that no officer in civil employment will be allowed to place himself out of employment for the purpose of taking leave under these rules, or for any purpose but immediate retirement.

2. Leave in or out of India commences on the date an officer is "struck off duty," which means the date following the day of relief, and terminates on, and includes, the day preceding the date on which he rejoins his regiment or appointment on return from leave; the only exception being in the case of leave out of India on medical certificate, when the precise amount recommended by a Medical Board to be necessary in any case reckons from the date on which the vessel in which he embarks quits her moorings or anchorage, and terminates on the date preceding that on which he rejoins his regiment or appointment on return.

3. In the case of an officer obliged to leave his station to appear before a Medical Board at another station, the date of being "struck off duty" will mean the date he is permitted to quit the station where he is examined and invalided. An officer so circumstanced is entitled to full pay and Staff salary up to and for the date preceding that on which he is permitted to quit the station where he is examined and invalided.

4. Under these rules, absence from duty with pay, which is restricted to two years, is reckoned from the date of being "struck off duty" to date of rejoining appointment or regiment.

5. Up to date of leaving India, and from date of return to India to date of rejoining regiment or appointment, an officer granted leave out of India under these rules will receive Indian pay and half staff salary, provided, in any case, the two years' absence from duty is not exceeded.

6. An officer subject to these rules who holds a permanent departmental or regimental staff appointment, promoted while on leave out of India, is only entitled, from date of debarkation in India to that of joining his appointment, to the Indian pay and allowances of his rank, and the half staff salary of the appointment he held at the time he proceeded on leave.

7. An officer holding a permanent departmental or regimental staff appointment, promoted while on leave in India, will draw the Indian pay and allowances of his rank, and the half staff salary of the appointment he held at the time he proceeded on leave, until he assumes charge of the duties of the appointment to which he has been promoted.

8. The Indian Pension Regulations are unaffected by these leave rules, except that all leave from date of commencement of service for pension will, under them, be allowed to count as service for pension.

9. Time passed at Addiscombe after the attainment of the age of 16 years will reckon as service for pension in calculating the rates of pay under Rule I.

10. The periods of service for pension in Rule I of the leave rules will entitle an officer taking leave to the pay fixed for such periods of service, without any limitation based on the rule* which prevents an officer from retiring on the pension fixed for a particular period of service, unless he has served half of that service in the Staff Corps.

11. The provisions of the rules with regard to duration of leave do not apply to probationers of the Staff Corps.

12. The limit of two years laid down for leave will not apply to time spent at the Staff College, which counts as duty.

13. Officers recalled from leave granted under these rules will be given free passage to India, or not, according to the Transport Regulations in force at the time.

14. Advances of pay to officers proceeding on and returning from leave out of India will be granted as heretofore.

15. Extensions of leave, except on medical certificate or in special or urgent cases in which the Secretary of State decides according to circumstances, cannot be granted without the assent of the proper authority in India as defined in Clause V of the rules.

16. Extensions of leave beyond one year under these rules are not claimable in any way as a right, but are admissible only at the discretion of the proper authority, and then on special and urgent grounds.

17. An officer subject to these rules on promotion to Major-General, or on attainment of Colonel's allowance, cannot be granted leave under them, and, if permitted to reside in England or elsewhere out of India, is restricted to the English pay of his rank.

18. Officers subject to these rules, who are in the following categories, and who entered the Indian Army or Staff Corps before the 1st July, 1881, may elect to reside out of India on the allowances admissible under them until succession to the Colonel's allowance or promotion to Major-General, whichever may happen first; or to remain in India on the unemployed Indian pay and allowances of their rank if unemployed:

(a) Officers vacating regimental commands, remaining in the service for the attainment of the highest retirement pension, or the Colonel's allowance.

(b) Officers over 55 years of age, who may be required under the rules to vacate staff, departmental, or civil appointments, and for whom other suitable employment cannot be found.

(c) Officers of the Commissariat, Military Accounts, and Judge Advocate General's Department, who vacate their appointments on attaining to 52 years of age.

(d) Officers who on the 8th August, 1884, were holding appointments of unlimited tenure to which they were appointed before the 1st January, 1884, and who vacate their appointments on completing seven years' tenure from date of appointment or such further extension as

---

* Army Regulations, India, Vol. I, Part I, Article 1333, Clause (e).
may be granted to enable them to complete 32 years' service for pension not exceeding nine years in all.

G. G. O. 310 of 1885.

(f) Colonels who entered the Staff Corps after the 12th September, 1866, and before the 1st July, 1881, and Colonels of the General List, after transfer to the Unemployed Supernumerary List.

The limit of absence from duty imposed by the leave rules will not be held applicable to these officers.

19. Officers who may have entered civil employment after the 30th June, 1886, and before the 1st July, 1887, without having elected the leave rules for the Staff Corps, will be entitled, on reverting to military duty, to elect them under the conditions laid down in the third clause of Rule VII. (See note to next paragraph.)

20. Officers who may have entered permanent civil employment after the 30th June, 1886, having previously elected the leave rules for the Staff Corps, and officers who may have entered the Staff Corps under those rules and subsequently taken civil employment, are absolutely under the leave rules contained in the Civil Service Regulations so long as they remain in civil employment, but on reverting to military duty within ten years of their entry into civil employment, as allowed under G. G. O. No. 135 of 1884, they again come under these rules.

Note.—An officer does not come under civil rules by reason of being transferred to a civil appointment, the tenure of which is limited to a definite period, nor by officiating for less than three years in the civil department.

21. Officers struck off the effective list of the army under the provisions of G. G. O. No. 135 of 1884, after ten years' absence from military duty, cannot elect or revert to the leave rules for the Staff Corps, except for the purpose of immediate retirement, with the advantage of counting all leave as service for pension, as provided for in paragraph 1.

22. The service for furlough of an officer, who at the time of coming under the civil leave rules, was subject to the leave rules for the Staff Corps, is calculated in accordance with the civil leave rules retrospectively from the date of his arrival in India, i.e., he is credited with an amount of furlough equivalent to one-fourth of his active service, less any leave out of India actually taken.

It is notified that all officers in military employ, irrespective of rank or the furlough or leave regulations to which they may be subject, who require an extension on private affairs of their furlough or leave out of India, must obtain the previous assent of the authorities in India under whom they may be serving, to apply for such extension.

This permission, when obtained, must be attached to their application to the India Office for the required extension.

Note.—This memorandum has been compiled for easy reference, but it is not intended for quotation as of official authority.

India Office,

August, 1893.
MILITARY FURLOUGH RULES OF 1868,

With subsequent amendments.

GENERAL ORDER BY THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA, DATED 25TH FEBRUARY, 1874,
No. 171.

The Rules previously in force will be designated, as heretofore, the Furlough Rules of 1796
and 1854.

The following G. G. O. are cancelled prospectively from the 1st January, 1875:

G. G. O. No. 630 of 1869 (1st Clause).
G. G. O. No. 627 of 1870.
G. G. O. No. 613 of 1871.

2. These rules are applicable to all officers who, on the 1st July, 1868, belonged to the several
Indian Staff Corps, or to the Indian Army, and who have
elected, or may elect, to adopt them: officers of the British
Army who entered the Staff Corps after that date are of
course subject to them.

(2.) In regard to the periods of leave of absence during which appointments may be held, and
in regard to the increased allowances, they are also applicable
to officers of the Royal Artillery and Royal Engineers, late of
the Indian Army, holding permanent staff appointments not
of a regimental nature, and to such officers of the Engineers
of the Imperial Establishment as may be permanently em-
ployed on the staff in India, or who are receiving a staff
salary as on the fixed Establishment of the Sappers and Miners.

(3.) Should an officer of the British Service, holding such permanent staff appointment, be
allowed to proceed on leave under circumstances which, by these rules, would involve loss of appoint-
ment, he cannot take leave under them, but simply as a British Officer holding no appointment.

3. These rules are not applicable to officers on the Invalid or Invalid Pension Establishment,
even if previous to their transfer they should have elected
them, being intended solely for officers on the effective list.

4. They are not applicable to regimental officers generally of the British Service, whether
formerly belonging to the Indian Army, and now in the Royal
Artillery, Royal Engineers, and new Line Regiments, or on
the old Line Establishment, nor are they applicable to officers
of the British Army holding staff appointments the tenure of which is limited to 5 years.

NOTE (1.)—British Medical Staff Officers holding administrative appointments in India tenable
for five years, who are compelled by ill health to return to England, will be allowed by the Govern-
ment of India in the Military Department to proceed there to appear before a Medical Board, and
if reported unfit for further service in India, will be removed from the Indian Establishment; if
otherwise, they may be allowed by the Secretary of State for India six months' leave on medical
certificate on their Indian allowances and half staff.

Such officers are also eligible for four months' leave on private affairs without pay, but only one
grant of leave will be allowed out of India during their tenure of office.

NOTE (2.)—All British Officers holding Staff appointments in India, except the command of
Divisions and Brigades, will be allowed, during their five years' tenure of office, only one grant of
leave out of India either on medical certificate for six months with absentee allowances regulated
under the furlough rules of 1868, or on private affairs for four months, with British pay, from Indian
revenues. Any leave obtained in excess of either of these periods will involve loss of appointment.

5. They are applicable to officers of the Royal Engineers on the Imperial Establishment, who
are employed in the Public Works Department, or who are
receiving a staff salary as on the fixed establishment of the
Sappers and Miners; these will count service towards fur-
lough from the date of their arrival in India.

(2.) These officers, therefore, and other Royal Engineer Officers of the Imperial List on
permanent staff employ under the Government, will be entitled to a furlough of two years after
eight years' service in India, or at the expiration of one year from the date of their return (for a
second tour of service in India) on the completion of the prescribed home service after the first
period of seven years' service in India.

(3.) Such officers will be allowed an advance of passage money, or free passage in a troopship
if proceeding in the trooping season; the advance to be refunded on receipt of the balance of
furlough pay. The English rate of pay of their rank only will be passed to them during their leave;
but at its conclusion, on their presenting an order for them to return to India, the difference between
that rate and furlough pay, less the passage money they have received, will be paid to them in
England, conditionally on its refund, if the order to return to India is not carried out.

(4.) Those Royal Engineer Officers who arrived in India before the 1st July, 1872, are, however,
not subject to the provisions of the preceding clause as long as they do not exchange Indian for
Home Service, but draw furlough pay during furlough, as others.

NOTE.—Royal Engineers of the Imperial List may receive their pay while on furlough, either
under the regulations in force before February, 1873, or under the terms of General Order No. 123 of
1873, that is to say, an officer of Engineers of the Imperial List may, at his option, on taking
furlough to England, either receive furlough pay on the understanding that, should he not return to
India, he will have to refund the difference between it* and English pay, less the regulated amount of passage money, or a free passage and English pay only during the period of his furlough, the difference between English pay and furlough pay, less the cost of his passage, being issued to him upon his return to duty in India.

2. The officer's choice should be made at the time of applying for furlough, and should be noted on his last pay certificate.

(5.) An officer of the British Service, holding permanent staff employ under the Government, who may proceed on furlough under circumstances which involve the forfeiture of his appointment, must obtain the furlough as a British Regimental Officer, and it will reckon as a portion of the aggregate eight years of furlough on pay to which an officer is restricted during his service by Rule XVI. But, on again becoming permanently employed, he resumes the right of obtaining furlough under these rules.

6. Officers of British Regiments who may join the Staff Corps can count as service towards furlough all their military service in India, provided that half of it (in no case less than four years) shall have been passed in the Staff Corps. But any leave to England they may have taken during service so counted will be reckoned as furlough already taken. Officers of the British Service who formerly belonged to the Indian Armies are exempted from the above proviso.

7. These rules apply also to all Warrant Officers holding Veteran or Honorary Commissions, who may elect them; the period of service qualifying for furlough being calculated from the date of the attainment of a Commission. They will receive during furlough half their total receipts, calculated as laid down in Rule V, but without any reference to a minimum or maximum rate. Warrant Officers not holding Commissions can obtain furlough under these rules only on medical certificate.

(2.) Such furlough may be for two years with retention of appointment and half of the aggregate allowances; but any extension of such leave (which will not be granted for more than one year in excess of the two years) or any leave taken within less than three years from the date of last return to duty, will be on "English furlough pay." [See Note (1) to para. 9.]

8. Every Warrant Officer who attained warrant rank before the 19th February, 1869, and who has not made his election, will be required, on the first occasion of his applying for leave out of India, to state whether he desires to take the leave under these rules, or under those previously in force applicable to Warrant Officers, viz., G. G. O. Nos. 518 and 531 of 1854, G. G. O. No. 1559 of 1857, and subsequent orders. That election will be considered final.

(2.) Those who became Warrant Officers after 19th February, 1869, are subject to these rules, and cannot elect any of the previous rules.

(3.) Leave on medical certificate on Indian pay and allowances to places eastward of the Cape, as allowed to Commissioned Officers under the Furlough Rules of 1796, is not in any case admissible to a Warrant Officer.

(4.) These rules respecting Warrant Officers apply to Honorary Assistant Surgeons and Warrant Officers in the Medical Department.

9. The term "Furlough Pay" having now a changed and two-fold signification, in all future orders and references "Furlough Pay" will be understood as the half Indian salary within the prescribed limits, specified in paragraph V of these rules, converted at 1s. 6d. the rupee, the privileged rate of exchange, whilst "English Furlough Pay" will represent the rates heretofore allowed to the several grades as English Pay under the rules of 1796 and 1854.

Note (1.)—Where in these rules English Furlough Pay is mentioned as that to which an officer is to be restricted, the rates laid down in paragraph II of G. G. O. No. 69, dated 22nd January, 1868, and (for Medical Warrant Officers) paragraph 22 of G. G. O. No. 550 of 1868, are to be understood as intended in the cases of Warrant Officers, Note (2.)—Officers who elected these rules prior to 1st July, 1871, or before G. G. O. No. 586 of 1871 reached their stations, will receive furlough pay at the exchange of 2s. the rupee.

RULES.

I.—The distinction with respect to allowances which has been hitherto drawn between furlough on private affairs and sick leave, is abolished, both kinds of leave being included under the general term furlough, provision, however, being made for the obtainment of furlough under medical certificate, without all the restrictions applicable to furlough when taken without medical certificate.

II.—Leave taken under the rules now prescribed will not involve forfeiture of appointment, except in the cases herein specially provided for.

2. All military and medical officers taking furlough or leave under these regulations retain their appointments during all leave of absence granted by competent authority. But their pay during such absence will be the same as they would obtain under these rules had this exemption from forfeiture of appointment not been granted.

III.—The rules now prescribed do not affect the provisions of Act XXXIII of George III, Chapter 52, Section 70;* but an absentee cannot retain his appointment and draw absentee allowances, except under the rules now prescribed. Nor do they affect the regulations by which General Officers Commanding Divisions and Brigades can only obtain limited periods of leave without forfeiting their Commands.

IV.—Leave of absence will in future be of three kinds, viz.:

I.—Furlough in or out of India.
II.—General leave on private affairs or sick certificate in India, or short leave to sea.
III.—Privilege leave.

Chapter I.

Furlough.

V.—An officer drawing staff pay in addition to pay of rank, proceeding on Furlough, will be allowed pay at the rate of 50 per cent. of the salary of his substantive office.

2. But an officer in Civil employ and drawing consolidated salary, will be allowed 50 per cent. of the average salary drawn by him during the three years prior to his proceeding on Furlough, or during his actual service in India should that be less than three years; and the time spent and the allowances drawn during any leave other than "Privilege Leave," will be omitted in the calculation of average salary.

3. No absentee shall in either case draw more than £1,000, or less than £250 per annum.

Note.—Should the Furlough pay of an officer in Civil employ be less than the Furlough pay of his substantive military rank, the difference will be paid to him as a charge against the department from which he draws his pay.

When the Indian Furlough pay of a military officer (combatant or medical) is less than his English Furlough pay, he is entitled to the latter.

The maximum furlough allowance, if paid in India, is the equivalent of £1,000 at the rate of exchange fixed for the time being for the adjustment of financial transactions between the Imperial and Indian Governments.

4. The term "salary" will signify the total amount drawn by an officer, whether as consolidated pay, or staff allowances in addition to pay, but will not include any extra or special allowances. But in the case of a military officer in Civil employ, his acting allowances shall be taken into account as a part of his salary in calculating his Furlough pay.

5. An officer absent on Furlough, who may be transferred to another office during his absence, shall be entitled, for the entire period of his Furlough, to Furlough Pay at the rate sanctioned to him when leaving India, whatever the salary of the office to which he may be transferred may be. This Furlough pay will be continued to an officer in military employ after his return to India and until he joins his appointment, provided it is not less than the military pay, or pay and allowances of his rank.

Note.—An officer promoted whilst on furlough to a higher grade in his own Department, is entitled from the date of his return to India to that on which he takes up the duties of his appointment to the pay and Indian allowances of his rank, plus the half-staff he was in receipt of, when he proceeded on furlough.
